/* Religion */ I smell heavy POV bias. The statement is overblown and pretentious - read the citations. They are bias, misleading and very very credulous. We cannot make such a claim until there is clear evidence. The citations base their claims it on anecdotes and a few sources that are questionable to say the least.
there is very strong consensus for this (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Turkey/Archive_27#RfC_Genocides). It's been there for ages.
Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/Khirurg|Khirurg]] ([[User talk:Khirurg|talk]]): Contentious, doesn't belong here ([[WP:TW|TW]])
there is consensus for including this

To place this statement in the lede is both deceptive and political. The event referred to is one of continuing political significance, sensitivity and dispute from the topic of the article in question. To put it forward as a statement of fact, without acknowledging Turkey's strong objection to the term 'genocide', is therefore biased. Also, the sentence describes something that happened during the Ottoman Empire and not Turkey, reducing its relevance.
/* Islam */ This is obvious POV bias since the AKP does not consider itself to be islamist and has not officielly stated it.
/* Islam */ What is written here is objectively false - https://www.pewforum.org/2012/08/09/the-worlds-muslims-unity-and-diversity-executive-summary/
/* Religion */  Final change, according to [[Islam in Turkey]] there are %16.5 Shia in Turkey. Adjusting accordingly.
/* Religion */ Adding 0.33 to Sunni to make it %100, currently at %99.67
/* Religion */ According to [[Christianity in Turkey]] there are 200,000-320,000 (%0.3-%0.4) in Turkey. Adjusting accordingly from %0.2 to %0.35

/* Religion */  According to the article [[History of the Jews in Turkey]] there are currently 18.000 (higher estimate) living in Turkey. The graph was placed at %0.5 (meaning 410.000). Fixed it according to 18.000 which is %0.02.

Armenia and Nakhchivan are more to the northeast (along with Georgia) -- all these are in the contiguous Transcaucasia

/* Etymology */ There is no evidence to prove that Erdoğan "reversed" Kemalist policies. What policies exactly have been reversed? Also freedom of speech has not been reversed. How does that make sense when opposition media is there, in fact four of five major news outlets are opposition. I freely criticise the government on social media and in local government. How is this a reversal of freedom of speech? It has been undermined and is in a poorer state, but not reversed.
